fields.descriptive_line: Theatre costume of doublet, 'Venetians', cape, hat, 2 collars and a pair of shoes, worn by Henry Irving as Malvolio in 'Twelfth Night', 1884, at the Lyceum under Irving's own management.
fields.physical_description:
[cape] Short, stiff cape of black silk braided with yellow, fastening with tabs to buttons on both shoulders.
[doublet] Collarless doublet of black silk with vertical yellow piping, sharply-pointed waistline marked by a padded roll, small sewn-in ruffles at wrists.
[breeches] 'Venetian' breeches of black silk with vertical double lines of applied yellow braid, caught down into puffs at the hips and fastening at the knee with three buttons. Fall front. Inner section fastens at centre front with a vertical row of three buttons. The front 'falling' flap, fastens on to this inner section with 5 buttons. Two functional internal pockets, one at each hip. Two further non functional diagonal pockets on either side of the centre front. 6 further buttons at waist for braces and strap at back waist for adjusting fit. Further black button at crotch, possibly used to secure doublet.
[cap] Bonnet of soft black ribbed silk. Circular padded brim appliqued with stripes of narrow yellow braid. Trimmed with ostrich feather at front.
[ruff] Very high stock (one of two) with pleated linen ruffs tacked to base. This ruff has been starched and is edged with lace above which is a border of feather stitch detailing in black cotton. The top section of the stock, which curves into a point at the centre front, is made from corded silk, striped black and yellow. This upper section is stiffened with canvas and faced in beige silk. Fastens with a tab and metal buckle at rear.
[ruff] Very high stock (one of two) with pleated linen ruffs tacked to base. This ruff has been starched and is edged with lace above which is a border of feather stitch detailing in black cotton. The top section of the stock, which curves into a point at the centre front, is made from corded silk, striped black and yellow. This upper section is stiffened with canvas and faced in beige silk. Fastens with a tab and metal buckle at rear. Much more evidence of wear than S.2758:5-2010 with make up stains on front.
[shoe] Black leather strap shoe, fastened with two side straps or latchets. These have been stitched down. Small heel and finishing in a softened point at the toe. Sole has been heavily scored to add grip. Lined in tan leather, with tan leather insole, edges bound in a narrow cotton ribbon .
[shoe] Black leather strap shoe, fastened with two side straps or latchets. These have been stitched down. Small heel and finishing in a softened point at the toe. Sole has been heavily scored to add grip. Lined in tan leather, with tan leather insole, edges bound in a narrow cotton ribbon .

[cape] Length: 56.5 cm including collar, Width: 91 cm maximum width closed, Circumference: 193 cm measured at bottom hem
[doublet] Length: 73 cm maximum, Width: 76 cm maximum width at shoulders
[breeches] Length: 84 cm waist to knee
[cap] Diameter: 25.5 cm
[ruff] Length: 40 cm (not including tab), Width: 15 cm maximum
[ruff] Length: 41 cm (not including tab), Width: 16 cm Maximum
[shoe] Length: 30.25 cm Sole, Height: 1.75 cm Heel, Length: 9.5 cm from base of sole to highest point
[shoe] Length: 30.25 cm sole, Height: 1.75 cm heel, Length: 9.5 cm From base of sole to highest point
fields.materials_techniques:
[cape] Silk, braided
[doublet] Silk, piped and padded
fields.public_access_description:
This costume was worn by the actor Henry Irving (1838-1905) when playing the role of Malvolio in the 1884 production of Twelfth Night by William Shakespeare. 

Twelfth Night was not popular among Victorian audiences and the play's chances of success were not improved by the heat wave which greeted the first performances. Further disaster struck when blood poisoning compelled Ellen Terry (1847-1928) to leave the production after only sixteen performances, and her sister Marion Terry (1853-1930) had to take over the role of Viola. 

Audiences were also dismayed by Irving’s decision to play Malvolio as a figure who was far more tragic than comic, and some actually booed at the end. Irving retaliated with a furious curtain speech which Ellen described as 'the only mistake I ever saw him make'. Unsurprisingly the production ran for only thirty nine performances in London and was never revived. Despite the failure of the London production Irving decided to assemble a new cast to mount a production of the play on the subsequent tour to America and this revised version was received much more positively by American audiences.

Henry Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learnt his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  In 1871 he joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman.  Irving remained at the Lyceum until 1902, taking over the management of the theatre in 1878, thereby achieving the status of an "actor-manager".  At the Lyceum, Irving produced a range of plays both old and new, including melodrama, Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  He worked tirelessly to raise the status of the Theatre profession both in the view of the public and among official bodies, especially religious organisations.  His success in this field was recognised in 1895, when he became the first actor to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Many of Irving's productions were spectacularly staged with large casts of performers.  He created desired effects of colour and movement using scenery, costume and lighting, set to music appropriate to the action, played by a full orchestra.  Although from the 1880s electric lighting was available for theatres, Irving always used gas, as well as lime-light (a form of spot-lighting).  Gas lighting gave a softer appearance to the general stage picture, whilst lime-light could be used to highlight Irving as the focus of attention at key points in the play.  Outside of London, Irving toured complete productions, taking the full London company, scenery and costumes, throughout the United Kingdom and also across the United States and Canada.  His was the first generation that could do this through the rapid development of the railway system.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 105, pl.XIV.
